question: can there be knowledge that is independent of culture?

clueweb22-en0000-22-15517.point_content: Therefore, we cannot have beliefs which are independent of our culture.
spans: Therefore, we cannot have beliefs which are independent of our culture.

clueweb22-en0000-22-15517.point_content: It is possible to have knowledge which is independent of our culture but it is not possible to have beliefs which are independent of our culture.
spans: In conclusion, it is possible to have knowledge which is independent of our culture but it is not possible to have beliefs which are independent of our culture.

clueweb22-en0041-52-12439.point_content: Claim: Can we have knowledge independent of our culture? Counterclaim: All knowledge is based on our culture, without culture there is no knowledge.
spans: Claim: Can we have knowledge independent of our culture? Counterclaim: All knowledge is based on our culture, without culture there is no knowledge.

clueweb22-en0041-52-12439.point_content: Culture is the characteristics of a particular group of people, defined by everything from language, religion, cuisine, social habits, music and arts.
spans: Culture is the characteristics of a particular group of people, defined by everything from language, religion, cuisine, social habits, music and arts.

clueweb22-en0041-52-12439.point_content: Since we come into the world, we become part of a culture. Our parents and guardians slowly push us into it, they teach us about values, traditions, religion and everything else that can be called culture.
spans: Since we come into the world, we become part of a culture. Our parents and guardians slowly push us into it, they teach us about values, traditions, religion and everything else that can be called culture.

clueweb22-en0041-52-12439.point_content: It is not known whether our opinions are driven by our culture or we are responsible for them.
spans: However, it is not known whether our opinions are driven by our culture or we are responsible for them.

clueweb22-en0041-52-12439.point_content: Culture can affect how we see migration, but migration does not fully depend on culture, as most of the time migration happens because of social factors.
spans: Culture can affect how we see migration.
On the other hand, culture does not fully depend on migration, as most of the time migration happens because of social factors.

clueweb22-en0041-52-12439.point_content: We can have views on migration independent of our culture, but we can also have a view centered by our culture.
spans: We can have views on migration independent of our culture, but we can also have a view centered by our culture, like in Australia.

clueweb22-en0041-52-12439.point_content: Depending on the culture in which we are raised then we can have an opinion on gay marriage, for example, religion, a part of culture is a determinating factor on the decision.
spans: Depending on the culture in which we are raised then we can have an opinion on gay marriage, for example, El Salvador is a country full of traditions and alive with culture, since we are born, most of us are introduced into religion, newborns get baptized without any awareness, parents take the decision and when children are slightly older, they are forced to go to church on Sundays with family.

The debate on legalizing gay marriage is still ongoing in El Salvador and this is one of the cases where culture can influence your opinion on a topic religion, a part of culture is a determinating factor on the decision.

clueweb22-en0041-52-12439.point_content: Ideology is key to understanding the claim that knowledge can be independent of culture, as people raised in the same culture can have very different views.
spans: Ideology is the way in which people think about several factors, and ideology is key to understanding the claim, as it makes us think on how people raised in the same culture and country and social background can have such different views about the world.

clueweb22-en0041-52-12439.point_content: Everyone has a different ideology and point of view, which shows that knowledge, emotions, reasoning, and logic do not depend entirely on culture.
spans: Everyone has a point of view, if they didn’t there wouldn’t be any diversity and the point of view would cease to exist, everyone has a different opinion, some are alike but there can never be two individuals with the exact same ideology.
It is part of reasoning, for example, people at the age of 17-18 are said to reason without logic, by rational reasoning.

clueweb22-en0041-52-12439.point_content: Knowledge is something every human being possesses and starts since we can reason; culture influences but does not fully determine knowledge.
spans: Knowledge is something every human being possesses, it does not matter where they come from, or how old, knowledge starts since we can reason.
Culture is a great part of a person’s identity and personality, in their way of thinking and how they view others.
We cannot say all knowledge comes from our culture, nor can we say that culture has no influence on the opinion of people.

clueweb22-en0021-36-12427.point_content: Culture is a shared store of values and beliefs common to a group of people, which raises the question of whether beliefs or knowledge can be independent of culture.
spans: Culture is “mankind’s primary adaptive mechanism".  Essentially‚ culture is a shared store of values and beliefs common to a group of people. The prevalence of culture in the life of the individual leads to the question‚  " Can we have beliefs or knowledge which are independent of our culture ?"

clueweb22-en0021-36-12427.point_content: All knowledge is based on our culture; without culture there is no knowledge.
spans: Counterclaim: All knowledge is based on our culture ‚ without culture there is no knowledge .

clueweb22-en0021-36-12427.point_content: Culture is the characteristics of a particular group of people, defined by language, religion, cuisine, social habits, music and arts, and we become part of a culture from birth.
spans: Culture is the characteristics of a particular group of people‚ defined by everything from language‚ religion‚ cuisine‚ social habits‚ music and arts. Since we come into the world‚ we become part of a culture.

spans: Knowledge is a familiarity, awareness, or understanding of someone or something

clueweb22-en0033-78-12106.point_content: Culture is the aggregation of a community's beliefs, attitudes, approaches, behaviors and the social artifacts that communicate them.
spans: Culture is the aggregation of a community's beliefs, attitudes, approaches, behaviors and the social artifacts that communicate them

clueweb22-en0033-78-12106.point_content: All “knowledge” — those things men consider to be “known” — exists within spheres of culture.

clueweb22-en0033-78-12106.point_content: Arguably all of it. Culture (both internal and external to the math community) influences which topics mathematicians choose to study. However, the end product of their efforts are fundamentally independent of human culture.

clueweb22-en0040-78-00435.point_content: Culture heavily affects how an individual acts and thinks towards others and could be argued that it can define a person.
spans: Culture heavily affects how an individual acts and thinks towards others and could be argued that it can define a person.

clueweb22-en0040-78-00435.point_content: Being independent from something can be defined as not having a clear relationship and not relying on something else, in this case it would be beliefs and knowledge being independent from culture.
spans: Being independent from something can be defined as not having a clear relationship and not relying on something else, in this case it would be beliefs and knowledge being independent from culture.

clueweb22-en0040-78-00435.point_content: This essay will argue that in a way, knowledge acts as being more independent of our culture than our beliefs, as beliefs are heavily affected by the culture we grow up in and different cultures we’re introduced to.
spans: This essay will argue that in a way, knowledge acts as being more independent of our culture than our beliefs, as beliefs are heavily affected by the culture we grow up in and different cultures we’re introduced to.

clueweb22-en0044-21-06783.point_content: Knowledge can be acquired through biological responses to stimuli and could be considered not to be dependent of culture.

clueweb22-en0021-08-14253.point_content: Mathematics and the natural sciences are universal in their application and hold true regardless of culture.
spans: mathematics and the natural sciences are universal in their application
there are aspects of these fields that hold true regardless of culture

clueweb22-en0021-08-14253.point_content: Basic math applies to all cultures and language applies to everyone regardless of culture.

clueweb22-en0021-08-14253.point_content: Mathematical techniques have been consistent over centuries and cultures, exemplified by Archimedes' discoveries.
spans: mathematicians have been able to use the same techniques across cultures as well as across time

clueweb22-en0021-08-14253.point_content: The laws of nature are always the same, regardless of culture, and have been known since ancient times.

these laws exist in much older texts, such as the Zend Avesta

clueweb22-en0021-08-14253.point_content: Mathematics and natural sciences do not require cultural variables to exist or to be learned; they hold truth that transcends any particular culture.

They are, in other words, universal subjects

clueweb22-en0021-08-14253.point_content: Mathematics can describe things in nature that cannot be seen through the naked eye and can calculate precise positions of planets without direct observation.

using mathematical formulas it is possible to calculate precisely where planets are in our solar system without ever seeing them directly

clueweb22-en0021-08-14253.point_content: The natural sciences depend on the scientific method, which transcends culture and is not a cultural invention.
spans: There is no such thing as the natural sciences as a culture

The scientific method is not "a Western invention."

clueweb22-en0021-08-14253.point_content: Truths about gravity or how to solve quadratic equations exist independently of any particular culture's mathematical or scientific methods.

clueweb22-en0000-43-13098.point_content: Mathematical and scientific laws and principles overcome subjective thinking and are universally understood regardless of culture.
spans: We have created mathematical and scientific laws and principles that do overcome subjective thinking.
Everyone can understand them, no matter what your experiences or cultures are.

clueweb22-en0000-43-13098.point_content: Basic mathematical statements like 1 + 1 = 2 are objective and have only one viewpoint, independent of culture.
spans: For example, think one of the most basic mathematical statements: 1 + 1 = 2.

This is an objective statement because there is only one viewpoint on it. One could not justify saying that 1+1 = 3, because there are no perspectives in this statement; any other response would simply be incorrect.

clueweb22-en0000-43-13098.point_content: The ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter is always the mathematical constant pi, which is an example of objective knowledge.
spans: Another example of objective knowledge is the relation of the circle to pi. The ratio of a circles circumference to its diameter is always the mathematical constant “pi”, equal to 3.14159 etc…

clueweb22-en0000-43-13098.point_content: Immanuel Kant said that many kinds of knowledge are not based on experience or culture, but pure reason.

clueweb22-en0000-43-13098.point_content: It is not possible to have a universal absolute truth on issues that involve subjective knowledge and cultural references.

clueweb22-en0019-46-10978.point_content: Mathematics is perceived as a universal language that transcends cultures, allowing collaboration across different cultural contexts.
spans: mathematics is perceived as a “universal language”
a man working in Moscow, Idaho will have no problems collaborating with a woman who researches in Moscow, Russia on the same topic of research

clueweb22-en0019-46-10978.point_content: Knowledge is a product of human beings who are themselves products of their cultures, thus knowledge is influenced by cultural values and contexts.
spans: “Knowledge” is a product (something that is brought forth) of and through human beings; and individual human beings are the product, or what is brought forth, of and through the societies, communities or “cultures” they happen to inhabit at any given time

clueweb22-en0019-46-10978.point_content: If mathematics is discovered, it is independent of culture; if invented, it is a product of culture.
spans: If mathematics was “discovered”, it would be beyond the limitations of any particular culture. If mathematics was “invented”, then it would be a product of those particular cultures wherein and from whence it arose.

clueweb22-en0019-46-10978.point_content: Simultaneous discoveries of mathematics in different cultures suggest mathematics may not be a product of culture but a determiner of culture.
spans: Some research on your part should provide you with examples of the discoveries of the origins of mathematics which occurred simultaneously in China, India and Greece and would seem to suggest that mathematics is not a product of a culture but is more a determiner of what a culture would become.

clueweb22-en0019-46-10978.point_content: In the arts, great art is often considered invented and a product of its culture, but its truth may lie beyond the culture of the artist.
spans: If great art is “invented”, then it is clearly a product of its time and place, its social contexts, etc.
the truth of art and art itself (and I am only speaking of great art here) lies independent of and beyond the culture of which the artist as an individual is a product.

clueweb22-en0032-60-02734.point_content: Students may have mathematical knowledge in cultural contexts that does not transfer to formal classroom settings.
